data.text:
Jack Lemmon, the brash young American Everyman who evolved into the screen's grumpiest old Everyman during a movie career that lasted a half-century, died Wednesday at a hospital in Los Angeles. He was 76.

The cause was complications from cancer, said a spokesman, Warren Cowan.

Through most of his more than 60 movies, Lemmon was the least glamorous and most approachable of movie stars - the good-natured, ordinary guy next door with a slightly skewed moral compass. He was a master of sardonic comed could convey urban frustrations so deftly that audiences identified with him and thus were able to laugh at themselves.

As C.C. Baxter in "The Apartment" (1960), Billy Wilder's Academy Award-winning film, he created the definitive comic hero for an age of anxiety, a salary man so eager to win a promotion that he lends his apartment to his married bosses for weekly trysts with their secretaries. As Ensign Pulver in "Mister Roberts" (1955), a performance that gained him an Oscar for best supporting actor, he was a callow but likable wheeler-dealer.

And in one of his most memorable roles, as a musician forced to dress up as a woman to escape gangsters in Wilder's "Some Like It Hot" (1959), Lemmon got engaged to another man because it was his only chance to marry a millionaire.

The critic Pauline Kael found him "demonically funny," while Stanley Kauffmann described him as "easily one of the most expert American actors of his generation."

But Lemmon did not settle for simply being a skillful clown. In 1962, after making 15 comedies, one Western and one adventure film, he sought out the role of a young alcoholic husband in Blake Edwards' "Days of Wine and Roses."

"The movie people put a label attached to your big toe - 'light comedy' - and that's the only way they think of you," Lemmon said in a 1984 interview. "I knew damn well I could play drama. Things changed following 'Days of Wine and Roses.' That was as important a film as I've ever done."

Things changed even more in 1973 when Lemmon took home another Academy Award, this time for best actor, for his performance as a desperate garment manufacturer who hires someone to torch his warehouse in "Save the Tiger." The actor had been so eager to get the movie made that he relinquished his usual large salar worked for scale, then $165 a week, after studio executives limited the film's budget to $1 million.

With that Oscar, Lemmon became the first actor to win Academy Awards in both the supporting and star categories. (Helen Hayes was the first actress.)

Lemmon received six other Academy Award nominations - for "Some Like It Hot" "The Apartment" "The Days of Wine and Roses" "The China Syndrome"(1979) "Tribute"(1980) and "Missing" (1982).

Wilder, who wrote and directed seven films with Lemmon, once said: "Jack Lemmon is a ham. And you can always trim a ham. Jack Lemmon always gives you everything."

In a second classic collaboration, Lemmon starred with Walter Matthau in 10 movies, many of them directed by Wilder. Their first pairing, in 1966, was "The Fortune Cookie," their last "The Odd Couple II" in 1998. Matthau died almost exactly a year ago on July 1, at 79.

Lemmon almost always played the timid, neurotic schnook to Matthau's tricky whirlwind. He was Stan Laurel to Matthau's blustering Oliver Hard Bob Hope to Matthau's smoothly conniving Bing Crosby.

Matthau, the son of immigrants, grew up in poverty on the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Lemmon was a child of privilege who was destined for Harvard. Jack Lemmon, Matthau once said, "is a clean-cut, well-scrubbed Boston choirboy with quiet hysteria seeping out of every pore."

They were friends in real as well as reel life. Both men always insisted that during their 40 years of friendship, they never had a single argument.

In the '90s, the two became major movie stars again with the unexpected box-office success of "Grumpy Old Men" (1993), "Grumpier Old Men" (1995), "Out to Sea" (1997) and "The Odd Couple II."

Lemmon was also a perfect actor for bringing Neil Simon's neurotic characters to the screen, among them the fastidious hypochondriac Felix in "The Odd Couple" (1968) the hysterical visitor to New York in "The Out-of-Towners"(1970) and the jobless paranoid in "The Prisoner of Second Avenue" (1974).

John Uhler Lemmon III was born on Feb. 8, 1925, to a life-of-the-party mother and a father who was an executive with the Doughnut Corp. of America and an amateur soft-shoe dancer. An only child, he was sent to the best private schools in Boston. Later he was made an unwilling witness to the disintegration of his parents' marriage. His fun-and-games facade and clownish cheerfulness, he acknowledged, were his way of coping with the complexity of his parents' relationship.

A track star in prep school, Lemmon fell in love with the piano at age 14 and taught himself to play by ear. In 1943, he entered Harvard, where he was an indifferent student.

During the last days of World War II, he spent seven months in the Navy without seeing action. (He would draw on this experience for "Mister Roberts.")

He returned to Harvard in 1946 and graduated in 1947. Borrowing $300 from his father, Lemmon went to New York to act. For more than a year, most of his earnings came from playing piano at a bar.

Eventually, the young actor began getting roles on radio soap operas and live television dramas. He made his off Broadway debut in 1947 as the star of Tolstoy's "Power of Darkness," but television paid the bills. He appeared in more than 400 live television roles and was a familiar face on the leading dramatic shows of the period.

Lemmon thought his Broadway career was finally getting under way in 1953 when he won a role in a revival of "Room Service." Instead, a talent scout for Columbia Pictures, who had noticed the actor on television, plucked him for Hollywood.

He was handed the role of the boyfriend of Judy Holliday's character in "It Should Happen to You" (1954).

Lemmon began returning to the stage in the early 1960s, and would do so throughout his career.

"After eight years of doing a few minutes of film a day, I wanted the satisfaction of really working and building on a scene," Lemmon told The New York Times Magazine.

In 1986 he tackled "Long Day's Journey Into Night," to play James Tyrone, the father in Eugene O'Neill's searing disintegration of a family.

Walter Kerr wrote in The New York Times that the one deficit of Lemmon's performance was that "this star still can't quite bring himself to let an audience hate him."

Lemmon's career took a new turn in the 1990s with critically praised ensemble roles in Oliver Stone's "JFK" David Mamet's "Glengarry Glen Ross" Kenneth Branagh's "Hamlet" and Robert Altman's "Short Cuts."

His last major role was on television as the dying university professor in "Tuesdays With Morrie."

Lemmon's first marriage ended in divorce in 1956. His second wife, Felicia Farr, an actress whom he married in 1962, survives him, along with their daughter, Courtney McCrea a stepdaughter, Denise Gordon a son from his first marriage, Christopher and three grandchildren.
